awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Do ecological feedbacks across trophic levels affect alternative stable states and restoration of tropical forests?
awd_abstract_narration:
A substantial portion of the Earth's wildlands have been degraded by past land use, species extinctions and invasion by non-native species. Degraded ecosystems often do not provide the same important services to humans as intact systems - including such services as erosion prevention, flood control, and support for wildlife. This research addresses tropical forest ecosystems that have been degraded by past forest clearing and the loss of native fruit-dispersing birds and asks why these forests are not returning to native species dominance despite the cessation of the original disturbances that caused their degradation.  It evaluates the interacting roles of widespread invasive pasture grasses, high levels of soil nitrogen, and loss of important native species (birds, a previously dominant native tree, and soil microorganisms) in stalling forest recovery. The work also addresses why the common restoration method of mass replanting of a single native tree species does not lead to recovery of native tropical forest. This research will provide badly needed information on growth requirements for endemic Hawaiian forest species and will help direct restoration actions to insure better success in recreating diverse native forests, which may result in cost savings for future restoration projects. This project will also train local students who will become the future stewards of these ecosystems.

Insight into the theory of alternative stable states, which has come to dominate discussions of ecosystem degradation and restoration, will be gained with this research. A key assumption of this theory is that current conditions create feedbacks or priority effects that stall change, thus hindering recovery of ecosystems that exist in a degraded state. Most research on this topic focuses on the role of particular individual feedbacks in slowing ecosystem change. Using degraded montane tropical forests in Hawaii as a study system, this research addresses the role of multiple feedbacks, including cross-trophic level ones, in interfering with, or conversely allowing, community development away from a seemingly non-transient degraded state. An interdisciplinary team will address the importance and interactions of avian seed dispersal, overstory tree composition, understory grass competition with dispersing seedlings, and plant-soil and mycorrhizal feedbacks in maintaining persistent degraded conditions. The research tests specific interactions between birds, plants, nitrogen availability and mycorrhizae using manipulative field experiments, greenhouse feedback studies and ecological modeling. Together the team will work to determine what combinations of management actions are needed to accelerate ecosystem change in the direction desired by land managers.

por.por_cntn:
In the soil under your feet lives miles and miles of microscopic fungi growing like highways underground. These mycorrhizal fungi do not cause disease or decay, rather they form helpful partnerships with the roots of basically all plants throughout the globe. Without this partnership plants in the wild cannot survive, but we know very little about the diversity and distributions of these fungi nor how they will be impacted by global change factors such as invasive species or habitat loss. One goal of this project was to assess the diversity and distribution of mycorrhizal fungi in a Hawaiian ecosystem that is being restored from non-native pasture back into native forest - a critical habitat for endagered bird species. A second goal was to better understand whether restoration practices such as outplanting native woody plant species is leading to the belowground restoration of mycorrhizal fungal communities. Finally, we wanted to determine whether the mycorrhizal fungi found in restoration sites were abetting or hindering aboveground ecosystem succession. 

By using DNA sequencing to get the "fingerprints" of the mycorrhizal fungi found in restored areas and comparing those to remaining nearby native forests (the target for restoration) we found that some core members of the community are the same between these two habitat types, but that keystone species from the remnant forest as well as host specific ones are absent in the restoration sites. We found that while focusing on aboveground restoration has led to some success in restoring belowground symbiotic fungal communities, the missing players are likely critical for the longterm success of native plants and that their absence could in part explain why, after 30 years, ecosystem succession appears to be stalled. We suggest that considering incorporating these host specific fungi for future restoration efforts may be a key factor in achieving land management goals. 

The broader impacts of this project include creating guidelines and applied strategies for the use of local mycorrhizal fungi in native plant restoration. These efforts have included partnerships and collaborations with various natural resource managers and their staff in Hawaii. This project has also provided professional training for four graduate students - one who is Native Hawaiian and two women as well as training for eight undergraduate research assistants and two postdoctoral scholars. The results of this study have been disseminated through local, national and international meetings by all trainees as well as the primary investigator. Our findings have also been published in the peer-reviewed literature. As we face this era of pressing global issues such as biodiversity loss due to climate change, this project provides critical baseline data on how land use alteration affects key ecosystem components such as symbiotic soil microbes.
